node.title: Friday afternoon looked a lot like the early days of the pandemic, as a new variant left investors holding their breath
node.alt: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney
node.description: At some point on Friday afternoon, news flashed up on trading terminals across the globe indicating the new strain of COVID-19 found in South Africa  — and markets reacted, writes David Taylor.
node.content:
["Friday afternoon in Australia was a throwback to mid-March last year.", "Forgive the\u00a0Frozen\u00a0reference but, it was back to \"into the unknown\".", "It's a key song used in the children's movie series that captures that awful dread one feels when they stare into a situation or scenario they cannot see through.", "At some point on Friday afternoon, news flashed up on trading terminals across the globe, indicating the new strain of COVID-19 found in South Africa may be resistant to the vaccine that's just been rolled out around\u00a0the world.", "It created a sense of panic, and some markets on Wall Street went into free fall.", "
One bitten, twice shy
", "The World Health Organization (WHO) called a special meeting to discuss the new COVID-19 variant.", "However, the comment that struck fear into the hearts of those moving money was that the variant contained \"a large number of mutations\".", "Investment markets analyst Evan Lucas says it has global markets worried, and for good reason.", "\"There's no doubt it's a risk,\" he says.", "", "
New COVID-19 variant emerges in South Africa
", "
What's a company worth?
", "That's a very broad look at the issue though.", "The reality is that the Australian Securities Exchange comprises hundreds of stocks that all have a measurable value.", "So, when news hits trading terminals across the country, investors have to work out how that information changes the value, and therefore price, of the stocks they own.", "It's no surprise then that stocks like Flight Centre (-7pc), Qantas (-5pc) and Corporate Travel Management (-5pc) all fell sharply.", "Analysts, in a short space of time, re-entered lower future revenue numbers for these businesses, effectively pricing in more travel uncertainty and potential international border closures.", "
Extraordinary external\u00a0shock
", "Here's the other problem.", "COVID-19 fatigue is real.", "Anyone who's just returned to the office will have had conversations with colleagues about how hard the past 20 months have been.", "Many are ready to enjoy a well-earned break.", "More broadly though, governments and central banks were up for a fight in March last year.", "Australia's budget was effectively in balance and the Reserve Bank had wiggle room to loosen monetary policy \u2014 and the stomach to engage in money printing.", "It's a different story now.", "The Australian government is now in debt to the tune of roughly $860 billion and the Reserve Bank's cash rate is sitting a shade above zero per cent.", "Another wave of the pandemic, sans an effective vaccine,\u00a0would be like a wrecking ball swinging into the economy.", "
Awkward time for another crisis
", "If that wasn't enough, one of the biggest threats facing the global economy and financial markets is a spike in inflation, seen most spectacularly in the United States.", "It's already pushing up US interest rates, which is seeing higher borrowing costs in Australia as well.", "Early on Friday, the Commonwealth Bank hiked its fixed-rate mortgage products by as much as 0.3 percentage points, its\u00a0third move in six weeks.", "It's another worry for investors.", "\"Shares remain vulnerable to short-term volatility, with possible triggers being the rebound in coronavirus cases globally and new variants, the inflation scare, less dovish central banks, the US debt ceiling and the slowing Chinese economy,\" AMP's chief economist Shane Oliver says.", "
Keep calm and carry on?
", "A lot can happen in a single day on global financial markets.", "And the past 20 months have been one heck of a ride.", "March panic morphed into on-going fear and anxiety, but human beings are a resilient bunch and, slowly but surely, we found solutions.", "The world was hit again earlier this year with surging COVID-19 case numbers but it was different \u2014 we had a vaccine.", "Now we face the potential of\u00a0a new surge in cases that we may be, as yet,\u00a0unable to fight.", "If that's the case, scientists will be scrambling to find new artillery to fight this new strain.", "And while that's happening, global markets investors, at least initially, are scrambling for somewhere safe to protect their money.", "It's a hard time for any investor to hold their nerve.", "", "
What COVID-19 travel insurance doesn't cover you for(Emilia Terzon)
